Lesson 2: New Employee Orientation

Image by Toa Heftiba under Unsplash

Imagine this scenario

It’s the first day of your new job. You arrive at your new job excited and maybe a bit nervous. When you get to the center, the person who is sitting at the front desk doesn’t know who you are. They weren’t told that someone new was starting that day. The director isn’t available because she had an appointment outside the center that morning. One of the teachers that you met when you interviewed recognizes you but is busy with her classroom, so she can’t really stop to talk or help you. You’re told to wait, and the director should be back soon. When the director arrives, she hands you a folder full of paperwork and tells you to read it and complete the forms that are inside. She leads you down to your new classroom and tells you to go on in and introduce yourself to the other teacher. She apologizes that she can’t spend more time with you, but she has another meeting that she needs to get to. You never see her again for the rest of the day.

Scenario Response

Instructions: What should have been different about that experience? Why? Use the reflection box below to share your thoughts. 

Instructions: Select the dropdowns below to read about employee orientations.

  • How long should an employee orientation last?
    • A new employee’s orientation should be an ongoing process for the first few months of employment.
  • Who should be involved in a new employee orientation?
    • It is important to involve more people than just the director. Include both management and peers so that the new hire can learn from multiple people. Bringing other staff into the orientation process helps distribute the responsibilities and allows for feedback on new employee performance from multiple perspectives. Consider assigning another peer staff member as a mentor to a new employee. This helps to create an intentional connection with another staff member and gives the new employee someone to ask questions of who isn’t a supervisor.
  • What should be covered during the orientation process?
    • Organizational culture – attitudes, beliefs, mission and vision, values and philosophy, etc.
    • Organizational norms – where do staff keep their lunch, ways information is communicated among staff (e.g. email, text message, phone tree, etc.), what is the dress code, etc.
    • Emergency procedures for the program.
    • Administrative processes, policies, procedures.
    • Benefits available to the new hire – professional development (PD) opportunities, etc.
    • Classroom expectations - policies and procedures.
    • Family engagement and communication expectations, getting to know the parents and children in their classroom.
    • Plan to announce new staff members to parents.
    • Expectations for performance observation and feedback during the first few months and then ongoing.
    • Other state licensing requirements for any specific orientation and training of new employees.
  • What do they need to know on day one? What is most critical? What regulations do they need to know right when they get started? What are the basic competencies that they need to know and that you can build over time?
    • Think about the first day vs. first week vs. first few months
    • Create an orientation checklist that documents all of the areas that need to be covered with new employees.
    • Prioritize the items on the checklist, letting those priorities create a logical training timeline.
